sentences.sentence: The first Black person arrived in what is now present-day Canada in 1604, and, while the social, political, and economic fortunes of Black Canadians have dramatically changed in the last four hundred years, the reality, in 2022, is that there is still a glaring lack of Black professionals occupying the highest echelons of Canadian business.

This reality sets the stage for the BlackNorth Initiative (BNI).The BNI is a grassroots organization, founded in 2020, with the stated aim of addressing systemic racism by increasing the representation of Black leaders in executive and board roles in Canada.The research on the lack of diversity in these spaces is abundant.

A 2020 Ryerson University study revealed that, while racialized people made up 28 per cent of the population across eight major Canadian cities examined, they occupy only 10 per cent of board positions.

The research exposes an even more devastating reality for Black Canadians, who account for 5.6 per cent of the population across the eight cities examined but occupy only two per cent of the board positions across the five sectors analyzed (municipal, education, hospital, voluntary and provincial).
Why and how does this disparity persist?

The study cited multiple factors for the lack of inclusive participants, such as a historical lack of exposure to executive corporate culture due to bias and discrimination, the inadequacy of social networks, and the artificial barriers to entry.The current reality in senior executive positions is equally disheartening.

Less than one per cent of Black Canadians occupy senior executive positions, and there are only a few, if any, Black c-suite executives in Canada's seven largest energy companies, six largest banks, five largest telecommunication companies and two largest life insurers.

As for the public sector, there are no Black Canadians as federal deputy ministers or federal court judges.It is against this backdrop and current reality that BNI created the BlackNorth Academy (BNA) in 2021.

The one-year bespoke online educational program led by David Beatty and Kelly Murumets, two esteemed professors from the University of Toronto's Rotman School of Management, is centred around business strategy, effective leadership, and board governance.We are the first cohort of the BNA.
We are Black professionals from across Canada, with varying backgrounds in accounting, aviation, engineering, finance, and law.
As professionals and leaders in our industries, we are committed to advancing representation in the boardrooms and c-suites to bring about meaningful change.

This shared experience and commitment to lifelong learning has led to our participation in the BNA program, which we believe is an excellent conduit to Canada's c-suite offices and boardrooms.The BNA program offers the opportunity to experience corporate governance and leadership in an authentic, powerful, and inspiring way.
Mentorship from senior leaders is crucial for any group wishing to get ahead, and Black professionals are no different.
This program allowed us to hear and learn from senior executive leaders who shared their journeys, personal learnings, and best practices.
The program and its various contributors, who are from all sectors, also provided insights on the tools needed to be a valuable member of any type of board or to hold an executive position.

The 26-week program included key seminars on strategic planning, negotiation, team effectiveness, leadership, and networking opportunities, within a safe space created by Professors Beatty and Murumets.

Within this safe space, we could freely share our individual experiences of systemic racial prejudice, discuss how these experiences were addressed, and explore ideas of how to make real and sustainable change in the workplace and the world.

Of primary importance to our group is how diversity can contribute to long-term sustainable competitive differentiated advantage and enable a company to be more profitable.While the BNA program is in its inaugural year, its value is immeasurable.

But, like anything new, to be sustainable, it requires committed leadership, access to corporate leaders who are willing to invest the time, networking opportunities, increased participation by the public and private sectors, access to the Institute of Corporate Directors' (ICD's) Directors Education?Program (DEP), and similarly situated programs.The work to address the racial imbalance in the c-suite offices and boardrooms of Canadian corporations has only just begun.
While it is too early to measure the effectiveness of the BNA program, it is a necessary step in the right direction towards impactful change.
